ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had synchronous seminars MWF and asynchronous assignments TTh. Sometimes, zoom tests on asynchronous days.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned a lot more Spanish than I expected! I went from knowing nothing to holding full conversations with my peers.
Well-developed foundation in Spanish language and culture

I learned how to speak basic Spanish, but I also learned how to study a language in a way that I haven't before, especially in high school. I practiced new ways to study and pushing myself to participate in class more was out of my comfort zone, but very important for challenging myself. I also learned how to ask for help when I was struggling by signing up for CLS tutoring and doing Linguameeting.
I learnt how to speak spanish proficiently. Im also now able to listen, write and read. I really learnt a lot in the short time.
A basic level of conversational Spanish.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths: great professor, easy to follow, lots of info 
Weaknesses:none except some of the assignments like the cultural project felt like busy work
Taught very well, the synchronous classes and Supersite balanced each other very well to develop a full understanding.

There are many little assignments (nothing is worth that much of your grade), which makes a lot of work daily, but also helps with retention and decreasing the stress of any individual assignment. I thought this class was the best virtual class I had and, although it is not ideal to learn a language online, my professor maximized the resources available to her and made the class the best that it could be.

The class was incredibly well structured. I felt like every class was well planned out and I would always learn something new each class. I loved the games we played in the breakout rooms and the many different media we engaged with during class time.

Strengths: You learn a lot of Spanish in very little time. The curriculum teaches the right vocabulary to be conversational. Profesora Pilar Asensio really cares about the improvement of her students, and she's encouraging and always available for feedback/help.
Weakness: I didn't mind how much work we had on Supersite, but because it's being graded by a system, the short answer questions could be very strict on how you phrased your answer. But also, with the amount of Supersite work being given, those few points are meaningless in the end.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms and Supersite were very useful.

The use of breakout rooms during class as well as full class discussion was helpful. Additionally, recording dialogues over Zoom worked really well. I can't think of things that could be improved for learning virtually because I thought the resources were used really effectively.

Obviously the course would have been better in person, but I would say the professor did a good job of trying to create an engaging environment even over Zoom. I did find the partner grabacion recordings burdensome at times because it's just an added layer of work to have to schedule a Zoom to meet/plan/record with a partner.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student because it is very well organized to help you learn the basics of Spanish. It is a lot of work each day, but there is available support and it is a very rewarding course to take.
I would reccomend it to everyone. I learnt so much

I would recommend this course, especially with Professor Pilar Asensio, to any student who aims to gain a solid foundation in the Spanish language. The course had a lot of work, but it was effective in very rapidly increasing my proficiency in the language.
